questions.neutral: Is the city acting weird lately?

hobby.message: The Council would flinch at your political literature stash.
Typewriters treating you better than people?
Got a new origami fold in your pocket?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I collect antique typewriters. They remind me of a time when things were different.
neutral_answer: The city has its moments. Strange these days, but not unexpected.
I keep occupied with my old typewriter. Simple routine, helps pass time.
Power cuts make even that unpredictable now.
Best to keep busy. Things adjust.
Things don't match what they used to. Everyone notices.
I've always spent evenings restoring typewriters. Keeps my thoughts clear.
Last blackout, couldn't finish a page. Annoying, but familiar in these times.
I suppose nothing runs smoothly now.
So I write by hand. Less attention.
Bit strange, yes. Energy flickers, odd faces on familiar streets.
I restore antique typewriters—been at it for years now.
Had a machine half-reassembled when the lights cut out, randomly, twice.
Ribbons are hard to get. Someone just offered me one, odd timing.
I usually keep my notes on paper. Calmer than the screens lately.
Not sure the system even notices these days.
Feels unsteady, Alex. Barriers shift, faces return you thought were gone.
Been restoring typewriters since before the BCI. Can't quite give it up.
Last week, routine blackouts interrupted my notes. Had to finish by lamplight.
A neighbor, vanished for months, showed up with fresh ribbons for me.
Makes you wonder who is tracking what, if anyone at all now.
The system’s gaps make even a hobby feel watched.
Still, I won’t stop. Ink leaves a record, maybe more than memory.
Definitely odd. The city was never this loose, not even years ago.
I worked for the Council long ago—typed every day, before the automats.
Restoring typewriters is my anchor. Still have a 1948 Adler, all original parts.
During last week’s outages, I was writing about Halden’s old protocols. Lost half my page.
A woman who disappeared from records returned, handed me a vintage ribbon unasked.
In the old days, routine like that signaled trust. Now, it signals nothing—or too much.
I move my typewriter around. Not paranoia, just old instincts. Never know who’s watching now.
Funny, with all their automation, a simple keystroke sometimes matters more than any algorithm.
hobby_answer: Yes. Old model, just maintenance.
Not much use for it lately, honestly.
Power outages have disrupted work.
People come around, offering supplies. Strange times.
Just keeping routines. Nothing remarkable.
Yes. Picked up a '48 Adler, needs a bit of calibration.
Had to pause repairs last week with the outages.
Stray visits from old neighbors, offering odd parts.
Can’t be too careful with exchanges now.
I keep most of it offline these days.
Things aren’t as predictable as they were.
New typewriter on the desk, yes. Been working on it for weeks.
Series 6, ribbon catch is stubborn as ever.
Power interruptions set me back again yesterday.
Saw some vanished faces dropping off old carbon paper.
Feels like restoring typewriters is resistance now, in a small way.
I write less, but keep at it—even if by candlelight.
Times make you more careful with your words.
Yeah, new project arrived—an Adler, pre-war design. Beautiful in the details.
Spent an afternoon fussing over its worn escapement spring.
Supposed to relax me, but power cuts are constant lately.
Had a stranger—supposedly gone a year—offer me a perfect ribbon.
These types of exchanges, once casual, now feel dangerous.
If the system’s watching, it’s confused; I hide work under old linens.
Most neighbors wouldn’t notice, but I do.
Journaling is more coded now—layers between my thoughts and the page.
Right, just started restoring a '48 Adler—reminds me of my father’s first.
I grew up watching him repair these, always respected the mechanics.
Last week, everything shifted—random power loss, doors left open, silent halls.
Someone who’d vanished turned up, offered rare typewriter parts, almost like old times.
I wanted to trust it, but you never know who’s listening now.
The BCI’s losing track—sometimes I wonder if they’re even scoring people anymore.
My writing habits changed—more notes by hand, fewer carbon copies, more hiding.
It’s odd, old machines never judged you. Now every act feels like a signal.
Some days, the sound of keys is the only thing that makes sense.
